elements.content: 5-[4-(N-tert-butyl-N-aminoxyl)phenyl]pyridimine (4NITPhPyrim = RL) forms a 1-D ladder polymer complex with Co(hfac)2 of stoichiometry Co3(RL)2(hfac)6, having antiparallel [CoIIRL] n linear chains (rails) that are cross-linked by Pyrim−Co(hfac)2−Pyrim rungs. The magnetic behavior above 100 K is consistent with contributions from one high-spin CoII ion (the cross-link, S = 3/2) plus two Co−ON units with strongly antiferromagnetic (AFM) metal−radical exchange (each S = 1). The χT data show an AFM downturn as the temperature drops. Assuming weak exchange along chain portions of the polymer due to poor spin polarization across the phenyl−pyrimidine bond in RL, a linear three-spin (S = 1, 3/2, and 1) fit to the T > 18 K data yields an AFM cross-linker (rung) effective exchange of J CL/k = (−)5.3 K = (−)3.7 cm-1. Superexchange (σ-orbital overlap) is a likely mechanism for the effective AFM exchange between CoON and Co spin sites in the three-spin groupings.
elements.clean_text: 5-[4-(N-tert-butyl-N-aminoxyl)phenyl]pyridimine (4NITPhPyrim = RL) forms a 1-D ladder polymer complex with Co(hfac)2 of stoichiometry Co3(RL)2(hfac)6, having antiparallel [CoIIRL] n  linear chains (rails) that are cross-linked by Pyrim-Co(hfac)2-Pyrim rungs. The magnetic behavior above 100 K is consistent with contributions from one high-spin CoII ion (the cross-link, S = 3/2) plus two Co-ON units with strongly antiferromagnetic (AFM) metal-radical exchange (each S = 1). The χT data show an AFM downturn as the temperature drops. Assuming weak exchange along chain portions of the polymer due to poor spin polarization across the phenyl-pyrimidine bond in RL, a linear three-spin (S = 1, 3/2, and 1) fit to the T > 18 K data yields an AFM cross-linker (rung) effective exchange of J CL/k = (-)5.3 K = (-)3.7 cm-1. Superexchange (σ-orbital overlap) is a likely mechanism for the effective AFM exchange between CoON and Co spin sites in the three-spin groupings.

elements.content: Co(hfac)2 forms a M3(RL)2(hfac)6 ladder polymer with 5-[4-(N-tert-butyl-N-aminoxyl)phenyl]pyrimidine. Magnetic measurements show strong antiferromagnetic (AFM) exchange coupling of the organic nitroxide units with directly coordinated CoII ions. Weaker AFM interactions between CoII−ON units through CoII cross-linkers are explained by a σ-superexchange mechanism due to coordination through pyrimidine groups.
elements.clean_text: Co(hfac)2 forms a M3(RL)2(hfac)6 ladder polymer with 5-[4-(N-tert-butyl-N-aminoxyl)phenyl]pyrimidine. Magnetic measurements show strong antiferromagnetic (AFM) exchange coupling of the organic nitroxide units with directly coordinated CoII ions. Weaker AFM interactions between CoII-ON units through CoII cross-linkers are explained by a σ-superexchange mechanism due to coordination through pyrimidine groups.

elements.content: Hybrid coordination complexes made with paramagnetic ions and radical ligands are of much interest to find combinations that yield higher dimensionality coordination and to investigate exchange behaviors between unpaired spins on the organic radical and inorganic ion portions of the structure. We previously reported cyclic M2(RL)2(hfac)4 type complexes 1 (Chart ) of Mn(hfac)2 and Cu(hfac)2 with radical ligand 5-[4-(N-tert-butyl-N-aminoxyl)phenyl]pyridimine (4NITPhPyrim = RL). These exhibit strong antiferromagnetic (AFM) and ferromagnetic (FM) M−ON exchange coupling for MnII and CuII, respectively, with weak AFM exchange between M−ON units. While neither MnII nor CuII forms extended chain or network complexes with 4NITPhPyrim, Co(hfac)2 forms a 1-D ladder polymer. Here we report the structural and magnetic characterization of this complex, 2 (Chart ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hybrid coordination complexes made with paramagnetic ions and radical ligands are of much interest to find combinations that yield higher dimensionality coordination and to investigate exchange behaviors between unpaired spins on the organic radical and inorganic ion portions of the structure. We previously reported cyclic M2(RL)2(hfac)4 type complexes 1 (Chart ) of Mn(hfac)2 and Cu(hfac)2 with radical ligand 5-[4-(N-tert-butyl-N-aminoxyl)phenyl]pyridimine (4NITPhPyrim = RL). These exhibit strong antiferromagnetic (AFM) and ferromagnetic (FM) M-ON exchange coupling for MnII and CuII, respectively, with weak AFM exchange between M-ON units. While neither MnII nor CuII forms extended chain or network complexes with 4NITPhPyrim, Co(hfac)2 forms a 1-D ladder polymer. Here we report the structural and magnetic characterization of this complex, 2 (Chart ).

</fig>

Layered solutions of 4NITPhPyrim = RL and Co(hfac)2·xH2O yield 2 as a dark-green solid with an elemental analysis consistent with stoichiometry Co3(RL)2(hfac)6. Excess Co(hfac)2·xH2O is required because use of excess radical yields complex 3 (Chart ) with stoichiometry Co(RL)2(hfac)2. No cyclic Co2(RL)2(hfac)4 analogous to 1 was obtained under any conditions attempted. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 2 at room temperature yields the structure shown in Figure . Table lists selected crystallographic and structural results. Full details in CIF format are available as Supporting Information and were also deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Databank.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Layered solutions of 4NITPhPyrim = RL and Co(hfac)2⋅xH2O yield 2 as a dark-green solid with an elemental analysis consistent with stoichiometry Co3(RL)2(hfac)6. Excess Co(hfac)2⋅xH2O is required because use of excess radical yields complex 3 (Chart ) with stoichiometry Co(RL)2(hfac)2. No cyclic Co2(RL)2(hfac)4 analogous to 1 was obtained under any conditions attempted. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 2 at room temperature yields the structure shown in Figure . Table  lists selected crystallographic and structural results. Full details in  CIF format are available as Supporting Information and were also deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Databank.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility (χ) versus temperature measurements on a polycrystalline sample of 2 yielded the χT vs T and 1/χ vs T data that are shown in Figure . Magnetization versus field studies on powdered samples yielded the M molar vs H data shown in Figure . Interpretive analyses of the data are given in the Discussion section.

Magnetization versus field studies on powdered samples yielded the M molar vs H data shown in Figure . Interpretive analyses of the data are given in the Discussion section.

elements.content:
Crystallographic Analysis Data for Complex2

chemical formula C58H38Co3F26N6O14 fw 1903.7 cell setting, space group triclinic, P1̄ a, b, c (Å) 10.2959(2), 10.4928(2), 18.2320(3) α, β, γ (deg) 93.4481(6), 94.2305(6), 102.2943(7) V (Å3) 1913.42(6) Z 1 density (Mg/m3) 1.651 radiation type Mo Kα θ range (deg) 4.09−25.01 F(000) 945 μ (mm-1) 0.792 crystal color dark-green prism data collection method ω−2θ scans collected/unique reflns 19 394/10 598 criterion for obsd reflns I > 2σ(I) R int 0.0870 range of h, k, l −12 < h < 12 −12 < k < 12 −21 < l < 21 reflns/restraints/param 6695/0/529 GOF on F  2 1.055 R1, wR2 [I > 2σ(I), 5370 reflns] 0.0785, 0.2177 R1, wR2 (all) 0.0940, 0.2334 temperature (K) 299

Crystallography. The ladder structure of 2 incorporates antiparallel Co···Pyrim−Ph−NO−Co···Pyrim−Ph−NO chains cross-linked by Co(hfac)2 units at the pyrimidine units. The 4NITPhPyrim units are somewhat twisted, with phenyl−nitroxide and phenyl−pyrimidine dihedral angles of 34.1° and 21.6°. Both CoII ions coordinate in pseudo-octahedral environments. The cross-linking CoII coordinates axially to pyrimidine (for the longest bonds, see Table ), with all hfac Co−O bonds equatorial. In the chains, the shortest Co−O bond is Co1−O1N1 at 2.022 Å:  it is trans to the longest bond, Co1−O3 at 2.081 Å. The short Co1−O1 bond length is consistent with AFM spin pairing between the unpaired electrons in the CoII and nitroxide. The Co−ON bond lengths in the related complexes 4 and 5 (Chart ) are short at 2.06 and 2.09 Å, respectively; these are consistent with their strongly AFM Co−ON coupling. The NO−Co−N(pyrim) angle is 89°, similar to that seen for the analogous unit in dimers 1, 4, and 5. The [CoIIRL] n chains in 2 are neither linear nor helical but are “step” ladders, with all nitroxide groups syn along the chain.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

 Crystallography. The ladder structure of 2 incorporates antiparallel Co⋅⋅⋅Pyrim-Ph-NO-Co⋅⋅⋅Pyrim-Ph-NO chains cross-linked by Co(hfac)2 units at the pyrimidine units. The 4NITPhPyrim units are somewhat twisted, with phenyl-nitroxide and phenyl-pyrimidine dihedral angles of 34.1° and 21.6°. Both CoII ions coordinate in pseudo-octahedral environments. The cross-linking CoII coordinates axially to pyrimidine (for the longest bonds, see Table ), with all hfac Co-O bonds equatorial. In the chains, the shortest Co-O bond is Co1-O1N1 at 2.022 Å: it is trans to the longest bond, Co1-O3 at 2.081 Å. The short Co1-O1 bond length is consistent with AFM spin pairing between the unpaired electrons in the CoII and nitroxide. The Co-ON bond lengths in the related complexes 4  and 5  (Chart ) are short at 2.06 and 2.09 Å, respectively; these are consistent with their strongly AFM Co-ON coupling. The NO-Co-N(pyrim)  angle is 89°, similar to that seen for the analogous unit in dimers 1, 4, and 5. The [CoIIRL] n  chains in 2 are neither linear nor helical but are "step" ladders, with all nitroxide groups syn along the chain.

a  Involves nitroxide N1O1. All bond lengths are in angstroms and bond angles in degrees; estimated standard deviations are in parentheses. See Figure for all numbering schemes.

Magnetism. The 1/χ vs T data for 2 over T > 100 K yield a high-temperature Curie constant of C = 6.27 emu·K/Oe·mol and a Weiss constant of θ = (−)5.5 K (Figure a). The Curie constant shows strongly AFM coupling in the Co−ON linkages with S Co - ON = 1. Using eq 1 with one average Landé constant for all spin carriers [g Co = g Co-ON = g avg] yields g avg = 2.54. If we assume that g Co-ON = 2.45 by comparison to values obtained5 for dimer complex 4 (a fairly close structural model for the Co−ON units in 2), then eq 1 yields g Co = 2.64. This is a reasonable value for octahedral high-spin CoII complexes.
elements.clean_text: Magnetism. The 1/χ vs T data for 2 over T > 100 K yield a high-temperature Curie constant of C = 6.27 emu⋅K/Oe⋅mol and a Weiss constant of θ = (-)5.5 K (Figure a). The Curie constant shows strongly AFM coupling in the Co-ON linkages with S Co - ON = 1. Using eq 1 with one average Landé constant for all spin carriers [g Co = g Co-ON = g avg] yields g avg = 2.54. If we assume that g Co-ON = 2.45 by comparison to values obtained5 for dimer complex 4 (a fairly close structural model for the Co-ON units in 2), then eq 1 yields g Co = 2.64. This is a reasonable value for octahedral high-spin CoII complexes.

elements.content: Below about 70 K, the χT(T) data (Figure b) decrease strongly toward an ordinate intercept of ∼2 emu·K/Oe·mol. A Curie plot of 1/χ vs T for T < 7 K yields C ∼ 2.44 emu·K/Oe·mol (Figure a). In the low-temperature regime, octahedral CoII typically acts as a low-spin species. Given the strongly AFM exchange in the Co1−O1N units, if S Co1 - O1N = 0 when the temperature drops below about 10 K, then only the Co(hfac)2 cross-links (Co2) contribute significantly to the overall magnetic susceptibility. Applying eq 1 to the Curie constant for T < 7 K with S Co = 1/2 and S Co - ON = 0 yields g Co ∼ 5.1. A typical value7 for octahedral low-spin CoII ions is g ∼ 4.3. Although 2 deviates strongly from Curie−Weiss behavior at low temperature, this crude estimate is consistent with expectations for a low-spin CoII cross-linker ion.
elements.clean_text: Below about 70 K, the χT(T) data (Figure b) decrease strongly toward an ordinate intercept of ~2 emu⋅K/Oe⋅mol. A Curie plot of 1/χ vs T for T < 7 K yields C ~ 2.44 emu⋅K/Oe⋅mol (Figure a). In the low-temperature regime, octahedral CoII typically acts as a low-spin species. Given the strongly AFM exchange in the Co1-O1N units, if S Co1 - O1N = 0 when the temperature drops below about 10 K, then only the Co(hfac)2 cross-links (Co2) contribute significantly to the overall magnetic susceptibility. Applying eq 1 to the Curie constant for T < 7 K with S Co = 1/2 and S Co - ON = 0 yields g Co ~ 5.1. A typical value7 for octahedral low-spin CoII ions is g ~ 4.3. Although 2 deviates strongly from Curie-Weiss behavior at low temperature, this crude estimate is consistent with expectations for a low-spin CoII cross-linker ion.

elements.content: The molar magnetization at 1.35 K (Figure ) rises rapidly to ∼2.2−2.5 μB at 15−20 kOe; at higher fields, there is a gradual rise up to the maximum measured field of 170 kOe. These data appear to combine contributions to M vs H behavior that are similar to behaviors seen in the Co(RL)2(hfac)2 complex4 3 and the Co2(RL)2(hfac)4 dimer5 4. This is not surprising if one considers the spin units in 2 to be weakly coupled because systems 3 and 4 separately have structural features that are combined in 2 itself. M molar vs H for 3 rises rapidly up to M molar(15−20 kOe) ∼ 2.0−2.2 μB and then saturates at roughly 3 μB. M molar vs H for 4 rises throughout 0−170 kOe at 1.4 K. Similarly, M molar vs H for related complex 5 increases nearly linearly at 1.8 K up to the maximum field of 50 kOe used in that study. We assign the lower-field, rapid-rise regions of M molar vs H for 2 (and 3) to the pyrimidine-coordinated CoII units in each. Unlike the case in 3, the magnetization of 2 does not saturate after the initial rise because of the higher-field, rising M vs H contributions from its Co−ON units, analogously to the behaviors of 4 and 5, which also contain Co−ON units. Although one magnetic orbital in the Co−ON units is spin-paired with the nitroxide singly occupied molecular orbital (SOMO), there remain two magnetic orbitals that can give rise to singlet and triplet states. As the field increases, the paramagnetic state of Co−ON apparently becomes populated, leading to the increase in measured magnetization.
elements.clean_text: The molar magnetization at 1.35 K (Figure ) rises rapidly to ~2.2-2.5 μB at 15-20 kOe; at higher fields, there is a gradual rise up to the maximum measured field of 170 kOe.  These data appear to combine contributions to M vs H behavior that are similar to behaviors seen in the Co(RL)2(hfac)2 complex4 3 and the Co2(RL)2(hfac)4 dimer5 4. This is not surprising if one considers the spin units in 2 to be weakly coupled because systems 3 and 4 separately have structural features that are combined in 2 itself. M molar vs H for 3 rises rapidly up to M molar(15-20 kOe) ~ 2.0-2.2 μB and then saturates at roughly 3 μB. M molar vs H for 4 rises throughout 0-170 kOe at 1.4 K. Similarly, M molar vs H for related complex 5 increases nearly linearly at 1.8 K up to the maximum field of 50 kOe used in that study. We assign the lower-field, rapid-rise regions of M molar vs H for 2 (and 3) to the pyrimidine-coordinated CoII units in each. Unlike the case in 3, the magnetization of 2 does not saturate after the initial rise because of the higher-field, rising M vs H contributions from its Co-ON units, analogously to the behaviors of 4 and 5, which also contain Co-ON units. Although one magnetic orbital in the Co-ON units is spin-paired with the nitroxide singly occupied molecular orbital (SOMO), there remain two magnetic orbitals that can give rise to singlet and triplet states. As the field increases, the paramagnetic state of Co-ON apparently becomes populated, leading to the increase in measured magnetization.

elements.content: Magnetically, 2 can be considered a ladder (Figure ) where J 1D is intrachain (rail) exchange and J CL cross-linking (rung) exchange. Because of the complexity of the system, a full analysis of all plausible exchange interactions was not carried out. However, assuming J 1D ≪ J CL, the ladder reduces to a linear three-spin-unit model with two S = 1 Co−ON units coupled through a central S = 3/2 CoII unit. This model was chosen because it seemed unlikely that the J 1D exchange interactions along the −Co−RL−Co−RL− chains would be strongly propagated across the bond that links the pyrimidine to the phenyl nitroxide unit in the RL = 4NITPhPyrim ligands. Although 4NITPhPyrim is conjugated and can, in principle, accommodate spin-polarized exchange across both rings in its structure, solution electron spin resonance and computational studies have shown2 that little nitroxide spin density delocalizes onto the pyrimidine unit of the isolated radical.
elements.clean_text: Magnetically, 2 can be considered a ladder (Figure ) where J 1D is intrachain (rail) exchange and J CL cross-linking (rung) exchange. Because of the complexity of the system, a full analysis of all plausible exchange interactions was not carried out. However, assuming J 1D ≪ J CL, the ladder reduces to a linear three-spin-unit model with two S = 1 Co-ON units coupled through a central S = 3/2 CoII unit. This model was chosen because it seemed unlikely that the J 1D exchange interactions along the -Co-RL-Co-RL- chains would be strongly propagated across the bond that links the pyrimidine to the phenyl nitroxide unit in the RL = 4NITPhPyrim ligands. Although 4NITPhPyrim is conjugated and can, in principle, accommodate spin-polarized exchange across both rings in its structure, solution electron spin resonance and computational studies have shown2 that little nitroxide spin density delocalizes onto the pyrimidine unit of the isolated radical.

elements.content: Schematic representation correlating proposed exchange interactions with structural features in2.
elements.clean_text: 4  Schematic representation correlating proposed exchange interactions with structural features in2.

elements.content: Equation 2 was used to fit the magnetic behavior of 2 by the three-spin-unit model, using an averaged Landé factor g avg and J/k = J CL (Figure ). J CL here is an effective exchange constant that can include contributions from the CoII paramagnetic, temperature-dependent, spin-state population variations and zero-field-splitting effects, especially at lower temperatures.
elements.clean_text: Equation 2 was used to fit the magnetic behavior of 2 by the three-spin-unit model, using an averaged Landé factor g avg and J/k = J CL (Figure ). J CL here is an effective exchange constant that can include contributions from the CoII paramagnetic, temperature-dependent, spin-state population variations and zero-field-splitting effects, especially at lower temperatures.

elements.content: This model did not fit the data well for the full temperature range, which is not surprising because of the electronic complexities of the system. Figure b shows the model curve fitted to the data where T > 18 K (but extrapolating the curve down to 2 K). The fit yielded g avg = 2.61 ± 0.06 and J CL = (−)5.3 ± 0.9 K = (−)3.7 ± 0.6 cm-1 (uncertainties are 1 standard deviation). Fitting of the data in the same manner for T > 40 K yielded g avg = 2.65 ± 0.05 and J CL = (−)5.9 ± 0.5 K = (−)4.1 ± 0.4 cm-1, so effects of the spin-state population variation in CoII do not much change the estimate of J CL at these temperatures. Inclusion of a mean-field Weiss term (T − θ) did not improve the fit significantly.
elements.clean_text: This model did not fit the data well for the full temperature range, which is not surprising because of the electronic complexities of the system. Figure b shows the model curve fitted to the data where T > 18 K (but extrapolating the curve down to 2 K). The fit yielded g avg = 2.61 ± 0.06 and J CL = (-)5.3 ± 0.9 K = (-)3.7 ± 0.6 cm-1 (uncertainties are 1 standard deviation). Fitting of the data in the same manner for T > 40 K yielded g avg = 2.65 ± 0.05 and J CL = (-)5.9 ± 0.5 K = (-)4.1 ± 0.4 cm-1, so effects of the spin-state population variation in CoII do not much change the estimate of J CL at these temperatures. Inclusion of a mean-field Weiss term (T - θ) did not improve the fit significantly.

elements.content: Scheme applies to 2 the same π-spin polarization paradigms as those used to explain2 AFM exchange in 1. The chain (rail) portions of 2 should contribute AFM exchange (J 1D < 0; Scheme A), so if J 1D is significant, this should contribute to the overall AFM χT downturn in 2. However, if J CL dominates, its AFM nature deserves explanation, especially because m-arylene units are commonly considered to be archetypical FM exchange linkage groups, albeit with some known violations. A π-spin polarization model for pyrimidine predicts FM RLCo···CoII···CoLR exchange (J CL > 0; Scheme B). However, although pyrimidine is a FM exchange linker in some cases, it also is known to behave as an AFM exchange linker. For example, Ishida et al. recently showed that dinuclear M−L−M complexes 6 (Chart ) all have AFM exchange coupling between the inorganic ions. The following discussion is based on this work and show how the three-spin-unit approximation of eq 2 with J 1D ≪ J CL can qualitatively account for the observed AFM exchange behavior of 2.
elements.clean_text: Scheme  applies to 2 the same π-spin polarization paradigms as those used to explain2 AFM exchange in 1. The chain (rail) portions of 2 should contribute AFM exchange (J 1D < 0; Scheme A), so if J 1D is significant, this should contribute to the overall AFM χT downturn in 2. However, if J CL dominates, its AFM nature deserves explanation, especially because m-arylene units are commonly considered to be archetypical FM exchange linkage groups, albeit with some known violations. A π-spin polarization model for pyrimidine predicts FM RLCo⋅⋅⋅CoII⋅⋅⋅CoLR exchange (J CL > 0; Scheme B). However, although pyrimidine is a FM exchange linker in some cases, it also is known to behave as an AFM exchange linker. For example, Ishida et al. recently showed that dinuclear M-L-M complexes 6 (Chart ) all have AFM exchange coupling between the inorganic ions. The following discussion is based on this work and show how the three-spin-unit  approximation of eq 2 with J 1D ≪ J CL can qualitatively account for the observed AFM exchange behavior of 2.

elements.content: Possible Qualitative Exchange Mechanisms in2
elements.clean_text: 1  Possible Qualitative Exchange Mechanisms in2

elements.content: Computations indicate that pyrimidine can provide a σ-type or superexchange mechanism that outweighs π-spin polarization effects (Scheme C). When paramagnetic ions polarize the pyrimidine nitrogen spin densities, a cross-ring nσ overlap gives AFM exchange between the ions. This confounds simple π-connectivity-based comparisons with the all-carbon FM coupling m-phenylene unit.
elements.clean_text: Computations indicate that pyrimidine can provide a σ-type or superexchange mechanism that outweighs π-spin polarization effects (Scheme C). When paramagnetic ions polarize the pyrimidine nitrogen spin densities, a cross-ring nσ overlap gives AFM exchange between the ions. This confounds simple π-connectivity-based comparisons with the all-carbon FM coupling m-phenylene unit.

elements.content: The qualitative exchange behavior of pyrimidine depends on the strength of its interaction with the magnetic orbitals of a metal ion. For example, Glaser et al. have argued14 that the AFM exchange between CuII ions in dinuclear complex {CuCl2}(tptz){CuCl2·(MeOH)} (7) comes from a π-spin polarization pathway involving the triazinyl ring and an attached pyridine ring due to the very weak direct exchange pathway through a long CuII−N(triazine) bond, shown as a dashed line in 7. However, M−L−M exchange in variants of 6 supports12c,13 the following typical generalizations:  (1) when there is good dσ−nσ orbital overlap at both nitrogens of pyrimidine, AFM exchange coupling is favored; (2) high-spin CoII ions will be AFM coupled by pyrimidine regardless of whether they are coordinated axial−axial, axial−equatorial, or equatorial−equatorial because high-spin CoII has both axial and equatorial (d z 2 and d x 2 - y 2 ) magnetic orbitals available to participate in AFM-favoring dσ−nσ metal−pyrimidine overlap.
elements.clean_text: The qualitative exchange behavior of pyrimidine depends on the strength of its interaction with the magnetic orbitals of a metal ion. For example, Glaser et al. have argued14 that the AFM exchange between CuII ions in dinuclear complex {CuCl2}(tptz){CuCl2⋅(MeOH)} (7) comes from a π-spin polarization pathway involving the triazinyl ring and an attached pyridine ring due to the very weak direct exchange pathway through a long CuII-N(triazine) bond, shown as a dashed line in 7. However, M-L-M exchange in variants of 6 supports12c,13 the following typical generalizations: (1) when there is good dσ-nσ orbital overlap at both nitrogens of pyrimidine, AFM exchange coupling is favored; (2) high-spin CoII ions will be AFM coupled by pyrimidine regardless of whether they are coordinated axial-axial, axial-equatorial, or equatorial-equatorial because high-spin CoII has both axial and equatorial (d z   2  and d x   2  -  y   2 ) magnetic orbitals available to participate in AFM-favoring dσ-nσ metal-pyrimidine overlap.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="chart" id="ic051884wc00003" position="float">
<label>3</label>
<graphic xlink:href="ic-2005-01884w_0011.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Figure summarizes the proposed exchange interactions in 2. Within the Co−ON units, one magnetic orbital overlaps strongly with the nitroxide SOMO to give AFM exchange regardless of axial or equatorial coordination, giving the observed higher temperature S = 1 state (J Co - ON ≪ 0, shown as a solid-line bond). In the same Co−ON unit, another Co magnetic orbital overlaps with a pyrimidine nσ orbital. J CL between a Co−ON and Co cross-link occurs through this dσ−nσ overlap, J CL ≪ 0. Across the Pyrim−PhNIT bond in the RL, J 1D is assumed to be quite small (dotted bond) by analogy to the behavior observed2 in complexes 1 and so is not shown in detail.
elements.clean_text: Figure  summarizes the proposed exchange interactions in 2. Within the Co-ON units, one magnetic orbital overlaps strongly with the nitroxide SOMO to give AFM exchange regardless of axial or equatorial coordination, giving the observed higher temperature S = 1 state (J Co - ON ≪ 0, shown as a solid-line bond). In the same Co-ON unit, another Co magnetic orbital overlaps with a pyrimidine nσ orbital. J CL between a Co-ON and Co cross-link occurs through this dσ-nσ overlap, J CL ≪ 0. Across the Pyrim-PhNIT bond in the RL, J 1D is assumed to be quite small (dotted bond) by analogy to the behavior observed2 in complexes 1 and so is not shown in detail.

elements.content: Orbital basis of exchange interactions proposed in2 with the three-spin-unit model of eq 2 shown in red in the upper chart. The lower chart shows a spin-array schematic for high- and low-temperature regimes.
elements.clean_text: 5  Orbital basis of exchange interactions proposed in2 with the three-spin-unit model of eq 2 shown in red in the upper chart. The lower chart shows a spin-array schematic for high- and low-temperature regimes.

elements.content: Lower-dimensional molecular coordination complexes can exhibit slow magnetic relaxation with unique magnetic properties in 0-D clusters. Some 1-D systems can also exhibit slow relaxation, as described by Glauber and demonstrated by Caneschi et al. in a paper describing the hysteresis behavior of a 1:1, 1-D helical chain complex of Co(hfac)2 with 2-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazoline-1-oxyl 3-oxide. However, ac susceptibility measurements on 2, collected between 1.8 and 4.2 K, showed χ‘ ‘ to be only about 1% of χ‘, so no further such studies were attempted.
elements.clean_text: Lower-dimensional molecular coordination complexes can exhibit slow magnetic relaxation with unique magnetic properties in 0-D clusters. Some 1-D systems can also exhibit slow relaxation, as described by Glauber and demonstrated by Caneschi et al. in a paper describing the hysteresis behavior of a 1:1, 1-D helical chain complex of Co(hfac)2 with 2-(4-methoxyphenyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazoline-1-oxyl 3-oxide. However, ac susceptibility measurements on 2, collected between 1.8 and 4.2 K, showed χ‘‘ to be only about 1% of χ‘, so no further such studies were attempted.

elements.content: Overall, it does not appear that 2 acts as a ferromagnet chain, despite the possibilities presented by having two different spin units. Of course, the overall behavior of 2 at low temperature is much influenced by the fact that the strongly AFM exchange coupled CoIIRL units contribute no net magnetic moment to the system at lowest temperatures, leading to a situation where the CoII cross-linkers are the only significant magnetic moment contributors.
elements.clean_text: Overall, it does not appear that 2 acts as a ferromagnet chain, despite the possibilities presented by having two different spin units. Of course, the overall behavior of 2 at low temperature is much influenced by the fact that the strongly AFM exchange coupled CoIIRL units contribute no net magnetic moment to the system at lowest temperatures, leading to a situation where the CoII cross-linkers are the only significant magnetic moment contributors.

elements.content: The complexation of 4NITPhPyrim (RL) with Co(hfac)2 yields a 1-D structural ladder polymer complex 2 with stoichiometry Co3(RL)2(hfac)6 rather than a M2(RL)2(hfac)4 cyclic dimer, as found for reactions with Mn(hfac)2 and Cu(hfac)2. The complex has a very strong AFM exchange within CoII−ON bonds that make these net S = 1 units. Superexchange or σ-type mechanisms through pyrimidine qualitatively explain the overall AFM exchange through the cross-links between CoII and Co−ON units. The complex shows no evidence of ferrimagnetic behavior despite having subunits with different effective spin quantum numbers that are nominally linked through the conjugated organic radical ligands. Although it is difficult to prove definitively, it seems likely that exchange throughout the structural network of 2 is significantly reduced by poor coupling through the chains (J 1D), across the intramolecular bond linking the pyrimidine and phenyl groups of 4NITPhPyrim units. The overall magnetic behavior is influenced more by direct metal−ligand exchange couplings than by extended coupling through the nominally conjugated network.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The complexation of 4NITPhPyrim (RL) with Co(hfac)2 yields a 1-D structural ladder polymer complex 2 with stoichiometry Co3(RL)2(hfac)6 rather than a M2(RL)2(hfac)4 cyclic dimer, as found for reactions with Mn(hfac)2 and Cu(hfac)2. The complex has a very strong AFM exchange within CoII-ON bonds that make these net S = 1 units.  Superexchange or σ-type mechanisms through pyrimidine qualitatively explain the overall AFM exchange through the cross-links between CoII and Co-ON units. The complex shows no evidence of ferrimagnetic behavior despite having subunits with different effective spin quantum numbers that are nominally linked through the conjugated organic radical ligands. Although it is difficult to prove definitively, it seems likely that exchange throughout the structural network of 2 is significantly reduced by poor coupling through the chains (J 1D), across the intramolecular bond linking the pyrimidine and phenyl groups of 4NITPhPyrim units. The overall magnetic behavior is influenced more by direct metal-ligand exchange couplings than by extended coupling through the nominally conjugated network.

elements.content:
5-[4 - ( N - tert -Butyl- N -aminoxyl)phenyl]pyridimine (4NITPhPyrim). This radical was made by a previously described2 literature method.

Co 3 (4NITPhPyrim) 2 (hfac) 6 (2). A solution of 0.160 g (0.34 mmol) of Co(hfac)2·xH2O in 4 mL of 1:1 (v:v) dichloromethane/hexane was carefully layered on top of 0.053 g (0.22 mmol) of radical 4NITPhPyrim in 2 mL of dichloromethane; then 2 mL of hexane was layered atop the mixture. The resulting mixture was allowed to stand and evaporate slowly to yield 0.125 g (58%) of dark-green crystals, mp 222−224 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C58H38N6O14F36Co3:  C, 36.60; H, 2.01; N, 4.42. Found:  C, 37.46; H, 2.08; N, 4.41. Crystal data:  C58H38F36Co3N6O14, M = 1903.697, triclinic, P1̄, a = 10.2959(2) Å, b = 10.4928(2) Å, c = 18.2320(3) Å, α = 93.4481(6)°, β = 94.2305(6)°, γ = 102.2943(7)°, V = 1913.42(6) Å3, Z = 1, μ = 0.792 mm-1, T = 293 K, data/parameters = 6695/529, converging to R1 = 0.0785, wR2 = 0.2177 (on 5370 observed data with I > 2σ(I)); R1 = 0.0940, wR2 = 0.2334. ORTEP diagrams were generated using ORTEP-III. Additional information was deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Databank, CCDC Deposition No. 288149.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 5-[4  -  (  N  -  tert  -Butyl-  N  -aminoxyl)phenyl]pyridimine (4NITPhPyrim). This radical was made by a previously described2 literature method. 

 Co  3  (4NITPhPyrim)  2  (hfac)  6  (2). A solution of 0.160 g (0.34 mmol) of Co(hfac)2⋅xH2O in 4 mL of 1:1 (v:v) dichloromethane/hexane was carefully layered on top of 0.053 g (0.22 mmol) of radical 4NITPhPyrim in 2 mL of dichloromethane; then 2 mL of hexane was layered atop the mixture. The resulting mixture was allowed to stand and evaporate slowly to yield 0.125 g (58%) of dark-green crystals, mp 222-224 °C (dec). Anal. Calcd for C58H38N6O14F36Co3: C, 36.60; H, 2.01; N, 4.42. Found: C, 37.46; H, 2.08; N, 4.41. Crystal data: C58H38F36Co3N6O14, M = 1903.697, triclinic, P1̄, a = 10.2959(2) Å, b = 10.4928(2) Å, c = 18.2320(3) Å, α = 93.4481(6)°, β = 94.2305(6)°, γ = 102.2943(7)°, V = 1913.42(6) Å3, Z = 1, μ = 0.792 mm-1, T = 293 K, data/parameters = 6695/529, converging to R1 = 0.0785, wR2 = 0.2177 (on 5370 observed data with I > 2σ(I)); R1 = 0.0940, wR2 = 0.2334. ORTEP diagrams were generated using ORTEP-III. Additional information was deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Databank, CCDC Deposition No. 288149.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility (χ) versus temperature measurements for 2 were carried out at 100 Oe over 1.8−300 K using a Quantum Design MPMS-5 SQUID magnetometer, using polycrystalline samples placed in gelatin capsules and held in place with a small amount of cotton; susceptibility data were corrected for temperature-independent paramagnetic contributions (χTIP) based on the high-temperature χT(T) data. Magnetization versus field (M molar vs H) studies were carried out on powdered samples at 1.35 K over 0−170 kOe using a custom-built vibrating sample magnetometer apparatus of a type that has been described elsewhere.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic susceptibility (χ) versus temperature measurements for 2 were carried out at 100 Oe over 1.8-300 K using a Quantum Design MPMS-5 SQUID magnetometer, using polycrystalline samples placed in gelatin capsules and held in place with a small amount of cotton; susceptibility data were corrected for temperature-independent paramagnetic contributions (χTIP) based on the high-temperature χT(T) data. Magnetization versus field (M molar vs H) studies were carried out on powdered samples at 1.35 K over 0-170 kOe using a custom-built vibrating sample magnetometer apparatus of a type that has been described elsewhere.
